Sunflower.passage: "The sun-flooded, sun-drenched sunflower, like the one at the top of this page, is a species in the daisy family and a native of North and South America. The name "sunflower" comes from the fact that the flower turns towards the sun to capture as much solar energy as possible. Sunflowers are known for their bright yellow petals and huge sunflower heads that grow up to six feet tall. Sunflowers are among the world's largest plants, and the tallest sunflower can reach up to 20 feet in height. Sunflowers are used for both decorative purposes as well as for food and oil. Their bright yellow flowers are a favorite of gardeners and have been used as a symbol of life and vitality. Sunflowers are often associated with the summer because their bright yellow flowers appear at the peak of the season. Sunflowers have a 360-day cycle, which is the longest of any crop in North America. Sunflowers do not require as much nitrogen, phosphorus or potassium as many other plants. Sunflowers were an important crop to the Native American population, who used the seed for food, oil and clothing.

It is characterized by its strong aroma and is also highly sought after in the cosmetic industry for its unique healing properties. Lavender is a highly-scented plant, and its fragrance is used in aromatherapy, soap making, and cooking, and the purple color of its flowers is popular for designing flower beds. Fern.passage:
Fern - wikipedia, free encyclopedia
A fern is a kind of fern. Ferns belong to a large plant family (Pteridaceae) that consists of several thousand species of the plant kingdom. This family contains more than 15,000 species in its family, many of which are still species that have not yet been classified. Ferns are commonly found in moist habitats, and they play an important role in ecology. The fern is characterized by the presence of fronds which typically have large, triangular-shaped leaves. Most of these leaves consist of multiple lobes. Some types of fronds also have more complex structure than others. Other common characteristics of ferns are the presence of spore-cases or spores. Ferns have many other common names, the most common of which are "sori" and "bracken". The correct common name of a fern is typically found in the first name of the species. In English, the word "fern" is used as an adjective. Ferns, especially those species which are the largest, typically produce the most common type of reproductive organ, known as a "spore-case", a structure that houses the spores. Spores are the pollen and sperm cells used to reproduce in ferns, but not in flowering plants. Many ferns have long and flexible lobes that are perfect for growing on moist rocks and other difficult habitat areas.

qae_pairs.question: What is the family of ferns?
qae_pairs.explanation: Pteridaceae is a large family of ferns.

The most notable of these events, is the rise and decline of large Pterosaurian air-breathing reptiles, which began in the Late Jurassic and ended in the Early Cretaceous. Robert Frost.passage:
“Robert Frost (Frost, Robert, 1874-1963) is one of the most celebrated poets in the history of the United States. He is best known for his detailed descriptions of rural life, including his New England ancestors, and his masterful use of rhyme and rhythm. He was an important poet of the twentieth century whose work was often marked by his personal pessimism. His fame and reputation as a poet was established by his highly popular poems, such as ‘The Road Not Taken’, ‘Stopping by Woods on a Snowy Evening’ and ‘Birches’. Although his work was not well-reviewed in his lifetime, Frost eventually received the Pulitzer Prize for Literature. Frost is also one of the best-selling poets in the English language, having sold over 2.5 million copies of his work in the United States alone, making him one of America’s best-known poets.”
It is very tempting to see this description of Robert Frost as a romantic, nostalgic, and melancholic person. And in a way, it does make him somewhat melancholic. And yet, he was a very successful poet who sold millions of copies. He is the most-liked poet in the United States. So why is this image of him portrayed as such a melancholy person in the passage? Africa.passage: "The history of Africa begins with the origin of the African diaspora, beginning with the out of Africa story of archaic humans, who are believed to have left Africa sometime in the past three million years. The migration has been documented in the Old World and its story is reflected in many cultures that have been touched by it. African populations are believed to have first left the continent between 80,000 and 60,000 years ago, and they have since made their way across Africa and beyond, leaving their mark on the rest of the world as well. As the populations spread out, different African cultural traits spread around the world, contributing to a global mosaic of cultures that are still recognizable in 21st century times. As Africa is the home of the great apes, there is strong evidence that early humans left the continent during a time when the chimpanzee population was growing. African populations migrated out of Africa some 40,000 years ago, and eventually came into contact with the Neanderthal and Cro-Magnon populations around 10,000 and 10,000 years ago, respectively, when the Homo species made their way to their new home. In the history of mankind, the Old World was a time when the great apes lived alongside humans, and as the Homo species spread across the globe, the human populations also migrated out of Africa."

Pteridaceae.passage:
Pteridaceae
Pteridaceae is a family of vascular plants containing about 6,600 species, mostly tropical in the New World. The family was first distinguished by the Swedish botanist Carl Linnaeus, who included it in the Pteridaceae family under the binomial name Pteridaceae, in 1750. This family contains the largest number of species found in any other family of plants. The Pteridaceae family includes both aquatic and terrestrial species in the genera Pteridium, Schimperia, Pterogonium, and Ophiogonium.

the Pocono Mountains.passage: "The Pocono Mountains are part of the Poconos (or "Poconos Mountains"), a stretch of the Atlantic Coastal Ridge between the towns of Scranton and East Stroudsburg in northeastern Pennsylvania, United States. The main range consists of the Pocono Mountains, which are composed of mainly sandstone, limestone, and shale formations. The range has been part of the Delaware Basin, the oldest of the four landmasses which make up the North American Plate tectonic unit, and which include most of New England. The elevation of the range varies from 1,000 feet at the highest (about 200 feet above sea level) to 3,200 feet at its highest point (higher than 1,600 feet) but is generally within 400 feet of sea level." the Northern Hemisphere.passage:
“The most widespread weather phenomenon is high and low pressure systems. Low pressure systems are found in almost all areas of the world. Low pressure systems are areas of low pressure relative to the surrounding high pressure. Most areas in the world will have low pressure (relative to high pressure) in the months between October and May (spring and fall in the Southern Hemisphere). Low pressure systems will lead to stormy weather, while high pressure systems will have less-active areas of weather. Low pressure systems will lead to cold air, rain, cloudy weather, and storms, while high pressure systems will lead to clearer skies and less weather.”
This is a quote from a page on the Wikipedia website called ‘Weather patterns.’ The page can be found by searching on ‘Weather patterns’ in Wikipedia or ‘Weather patterns in Wikipedia’ in most search engines.
